RESEARCH INTERESTS
The long-term aim of my work is to improve the design of interfaces that support visual information processing. I am interested in interaction design for normally sited individuals and those with additional needs. Processing visual information involves eye movements, perceptions, visual short-term memory and decisions that individually take only tens of milliseconds but that combine to give sequences of purposeful behavior that are more-or-less-well supported by interaction design. Small, apparently innocuous choices concerning, for example, the layout of pictures in a search engine can have a big impact on the time course of interaction. The consequences of these kinds of design decisions can only be understood through detailed theoretical and empirical science. My work is aimed at promoting design for efficient visual interaction.
Design Cognition: | Interaction Design | Human-Computer Interaction |
My research interests are in design cognition, and particularly in how to design human computer interaction so as to capture the adaptive nature of human behaviour. I study how outcomes (rewards and penalties, or valence - intrinsic attractiveness and aversiveness) associated with the past interactions in a task environment affect the way people interact in the current task, and accordingly how to design a system to induce people to adapt new and better strategies to achieve their goals. I also study how people process information, what determines the information that they see and attend to, and what information they ignore or suppress. The work is aimed at supporting better interaction design and to improve the compatibility between systems and the way people attend, perceive, think, remember, decide and act.
Approaches: | Bounded Optimality | Eye Movements | Computational Cognitive Modeling | 
I approach the issues of human adaptive cognition and interaction design with the methodology of bounded optimality (see Howes Lewis & Vera, 2009 for a review). The simple idea is that the adaptive cognition in a task can be understood by the joint constraints of hardwired human biological architecture (neural firing rate, perception, memory), the physical properties of the task (design) and the measurable quantified payoff function. New design can break the original task constraints and provide suitable reward function to induce adaptation. A better interaction design can be seen as a system which allow individual to develop a new way to earn more utility in the same task but with the new physical properties of the task environment.
I use behavior experiments and eyetracking methodology to observer where, when and what people look at so as to unveil how prior experience (memory) and expectations (knowledge) of information in a task mediate the deployment of attention and the way people interact with a system. Then, I use computational cognitive models to explore the underlying adaptive cognition to the joint constraints of the human processing system and probabilistic task environment.
